div1.p: Carter offers a correction to Bruce's “History of the University of Virginia.“

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Philip A. Bruce, June 24, 1922
div1.opener:
12
EG
/LC
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
June 24, 1922
Dr. Philip A. Bruce, LL.B., LL.D.,
Care Alumni Association,
University of Virginia, Va.,
Dear Doctor Bruce:
div1.p:
My attention is called to an error in your History of the
University (Vol. Four: Page 210):

1/ Dr. Gorgas was his own Chief of the Sanitary Department in
Panama and, while I was the next ranking officer under him, to Gorgas
himself should go the credit of the elimination of yellow fever from the
Isthmus.

2/ Instead of “taking” my “cue from Reed,” it would be more cor-
rect to say that I gave him his. My distinctive part as regards yel-
low fever, at this time, was rather research than executive work. My
exposition of the extrinsic incubation of yellow fever in 1899 and 1900
determined the direction of Reed's human experimentation at Quemados
and was the basis on which his work was undertaken.

I suppose you got this information from some of the Medical Staff
of the University of Virginia. If so, it simply shows how little in-
terest is taken in tropical medicine by our northern schools, even
in the work of their own men. You will find an account of this in
Reed's first paper, “A Preliminary Note on the Conveyance of Yellow
Fever.” published in the Journal of the A. M. A. in the fall of 1900:
In Gorgas' little book, “Sanitation in Panama,”and in an editorial--
by Gorgas, I think--in the Southern Medical Journal of the summer of
1915. Indeed, I think it is quite well known to students of tropical
medicine generally.

I have just returned from South America--hence my delay in reading
your very interesting History.

closer.signed:
Assistant Surgeon General H. R. Carter
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
